intro: Cochlearia campylocarpa, commonly known as the round-capsied rock-cress, is a flowering plant native to the British Isles. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many other flowering plants with small, four-petaled flowers. The plant is characterized by its low-growing habit, with basal leaves that are typically lobed or toothed. Its flowers are usually white or pale yellow, and it produces small, rounded silique fruits. Cochlearia campylocarpa is often found in coastal and calcareous habitats, thriving in well-drained soils.
